dataIdInfo.idAbs: Erases the values of a raster for areas defined by a feature class or raster. The coincident areas of the input raster will be replaced with NoData, or optionally, a specified numeric value in the output raster.

tool.name: EraseRasterValues

param.name: in_raster
param.dialogReference: Input raster from which values (cells) will be erased. It can be integer or floating point raster.
param.pythonReference: Input raster from which values (cells) will be erased. It can be integer or floating point raster.

param.name: in_erase_data
param.displayname: Input erase area feature class or raster
param.dialogReference:
Input feature class or raster that defines the area of cells to be erased.

By default the cells in the input raster that that coincide with these areas will be erased with NoData. If a value is specified for the Erase value parameter, that value will be used to replace these areas in the output raster.
param.pythonReference:
Input feature class or raster that defines the area of cells to be erased.

By default the cells in the input raster that that coincide with these areas will be erased with NoData. If a value is specified for the Erase value parameter, that value will be used to replace these areas in the output raster.

param.name: out_raster
param.dialogReference:
The output raster.

Cells that fall within the erase area will be NoData in the output, or the Erase value if specified.
param.pythonReference:
The output raster.

Cells that fall within the erase area will be NoData in the output, or the Erase value if specified.

param.name: erase_value
param.dialogReference:
The value in the output raster for the areas to be erased.

By default (empty) the cells in the input raster that that coincide with the erase areas will be replace with NoData. If specifying a value it must be numeric. The value is dependant on the pixel type of the input raster.
param.pythonReference:
The value in the output raster for the areas to be erased.

By default (empty) the cells in the input raster that that coincide with the erase areas will be replace with NoData. If specifying a value it must be numeric. The value is dependant on the pixel type of the input raster.

tool.summary: Erases the values of a raster for areas defined by a feature class or raster. The coincident areas of the input raster will be replaced with NoData, or optionally, a specified numeric value in the output raster.
tool.usage:
• The pixel type of this input raster will be maintained in the output raster.

  • The input Erase data set can be a raster or feature class (point, line, or polygon).

  • If the input Erase data is a raster, all cell that have a value (not Null) are included in the erase area.

  • By default the Erase Value is empty and will return NoData (Null) in the output raster. Optionally a numeric value can be specified. Strings are not allowed.

  • The Erase Value is dependant on the pixel type of the input raster. Thus float values are only allowed for floating point input raster. Invalid values will be truncated.

  • The output raster will have the cellsize and extent of the input raster by default.

  • This tool requires an available Spatial Analyst licence.

  • The following environment setting affect this tool:

    • General: Current Workspace, Scratch Workspace, Output Coordinate system, Output Extent, Snap Raster.

    • Raster Analysis: Cell size, Mask

scriptExample.title: Erase Raster Values tool example 1 (Python window)
scriptExample.para: This example takes an input raster and blanks out the areas of a polygon feature class with NoData.
scriptExample.code: import arcpy from arcpy.env import env env.workspace = "C:/sapyexamples/data" arcpy.AddToolbox(r"C:\pythontoolbox\Spatial Analyst Supplemental Tools.pyt") arcpy.EraseRasterValues_sas("surfaceraster","restrictedareas","C:/sapyexamples/output/fgdb.gdb/surface_restricted","")

scriptExample.title: Erase Raster Values tool example 2 (stand-alone python)
scriptExample.para: This example takes an input raster and blanks out the areas of a polygon feature class with a value of zero.
scriptExample.code:
# Name: EraseRasterValues_Ex_02.py # Description: Erase raster values with zero for polygon areas # Requirements: Spatial Analyst Extension
# Import system modules import arcpy from arcpy import env
# Set environment settings env.workspace = "C:/sapyexamples/data"
# Set local variables inRaster = "surfaceraster" inEraseFeatures = "restrictedareas" outRaster = "C:/sapyexamples/output/fgdb.gdb/surface_restricted02" inEraseValue = 0
# Check out the ArcGIS Spatial Analyst license and add toolbox arcpy.CheckOutExtension("Spatial") arcpy.AddToolbox(r"C:\pythontoolbox\Spatial Analyst Supplemental Tools.pyt")
# Execute tool arcpy.EraseRasterValues_sas(inRaster ,inEraseFeatures ,outRaster, inEraseValue )
